intro: Mitracarpus flagellatus, commonly known as the red sandalwood, is a flowering plant native to the Caribbean and parts of Central America. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its striking red flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 5 meters. Its leaves are opposite and ovate, with a glossy surface, while its fruits are capsule-like and contain several seeds. Due to its ornamental value and historical use in traditional medicine, it is sometimes cultivated in tropical gardens.
